content.question: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. Strontium hydroxide dissolves in water according to the following equation. The <math alttext="K sub s p" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></math> expression for strontium hydroxide is provided. <math alttext="S r, open parenthesis, O H, close parenthesis, 2, solid, is in equilibrium with, S r with a positive 2 charge, aqueous, plus 2 O H with a negative 1 charge, aqueous, K sub s p, equals, the molar concentration of S r with a positive 2 charge, times the molar concentration of O H with a negative 1 charge, squared" overflow="scroll"><mi>Sr</mi><mpadded><msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>OH</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mpadded><mpadded><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>s</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>⇄</mo><msup><mi>Sr</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo> </mo><msup><mi>OH</mi><mo>-</mo></msup><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mpadded><mo>[</mo><mpadded><msup><mi>Sr</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mpadded><mo>]</mo></mpadded></mpadded><msup><mpadded><mo>[</mo><mpadded><msup><mi>OH</mi><mo>-</mo></msup></mpadded><mo>]</mo></mpadded><mn>2</mn></msup></math> (a) A student draws the particulate diagram shown to represent the ions present in an aqueous solution of <math alttext="S r, open parenthesis, O H, close parenthesis, 2" overflow="scroll"> <mi>Sr</mi> <msub> <mrow> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mi>OH</mi> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> </mrow> <mn>2</mn> </msub> </math>. (Water molecules are intentionally omitted.) Identify the error in the student’s drawing.

frqParts.text: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. Strontium hydroxide dissolves in water according to the following equation. The <math alttext="K sub s p" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></math> expression for strontium hydroxide is provided. <math alttext="S r, open parenthesis, O H, close parenthesis, 2, solid, is in equilibrium with, S r with a positive 2 charge, aqueous, plus 2 O H with a negative 1 charge, aqueous, K sub s p, equals, the molar concentration of S r with a positive 2 charge, times the molar concentration of O H with a negative 1 charge, squared" overflow="scroll"><mi>Sr</mi><mpadded><msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>OH</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mpadded><mpadded><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>s</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>⇄</mo><msup><mi>Sr</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo> </mo><msup><mi>OH</mi><mo>-</mo></msup><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mpadded><mo>[</mo><mpadded><msup><mi>Sr</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mpadded><mo>]</mo></mpadded></mpadded><msup><mpadded><mo>[</mo><mpadded><msup><mi>OH</mi><mo>-</mo></msup></mpadded><mo>]</mo></mpadded><mn>2</mn></msup></math> (a) A student draws the particulate diagram shown to represent the ions present in an aqueous solution of <math alttext="S r, open parenthesis, O H, close parenthesis, 2" overflow="scroll"> <mi>Sr</mi> <msub> <mrow> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mi>OH</mi> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> </mrow> <mn>2</mn> </msub> </math>. (Water molecules are intentionally omitted.) Identify the error in the student’s drawing.

(b) The student prepares a saturated solution by adding excess <math alttext="S r, open parenthesis, O H, close parenthesis, 2, solid" overflow="scroll"><mi>Sr</mi><msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>OH</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>s</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> to distilled water and stirring until no more solid dissolves. The student then determines that <math alttext="the molar concentration of S r with a positive 2 charge equals, 0.043 molar" overflow="scroll"> <mo stretchy="false">[</mo> <msup> <mi>Sr</mi> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> <mo>+</mo> </mrow> </msup> <mo stretchy="false">]</mo> <mo>=</mo> <mn>0.043</mn> <mspace width="0.25em"> </mspace> <mi>M</mi> </math> in the solution. (i) Calculate the value of <math alttext="the molar concentration of O H with a negative 1 charge" overflow="scroll"> <mo stretchy="false">[</mo> <msup> <mi>OH</mi> <mo>-</mo> </msup> <mo stretchy="false">]</mo> </math> in the solution.

(ii) Calculate the value of <math alttext="K sub s p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></math> for <math alttext="S r, open parenthesis, O H, close parenthesis, 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Sr</mi><msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>OH</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></math>.

(c) The student prepares a second saturated solution of <math alttext="S r, open parenthesis, O H, close parenthesis, 2" overflow="scroll"><mi>Sr</mi><msub><mfenced><mi>OH</mi></mfenced><mn>2</mn></msub></math> in aqueous <math alttext="0.10 molar of S r, open parenthesis, N O 3, close parenthesis, 2" overflow="scroll"> <mn>0.10</mn> <mspace width="0.25em"> </mspace> <mi>M</mi> <mspace width="0.25em"> </mspace> <mi>Sr</mi> <msub> <mrow> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <msub> <mi>NO</mi> <mn>3</mn> </msub> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> </mrow> <mn>2</mn> </msub> </math> instead of water. Will the value of <math alttext="the molar concentration of O H with a negative 1 charge" overflow="scroll"> <mo stretchy="false">[</mo> <msup> <mi>OH</mi> <mo>-</mo> </msup> <mo stretchy="false">]</mo> </math> in the second solution be greater than, less than, or equal to the value in the first solution? Justify your answer. (Assume constant temperature.)

skill.text: 2.F: Explain how modifications to an experimental procedure will alter results.
